comments:
When I click in Eclipse on any operation that requires the file browser to open
Eclipse and the JVM crash. It happens on GNOME 2.8 but not on KDE 3.2. I tried
it with Eclipse RC2 and RC3 and it remains the same.

I use Mandriva Limited Edition 2005 for x86_64 on an AMD Athlon 64 3200+. I use
SUN's J2SDK 1.5.0_03 for x86_64 and Eclipse RC3 for x86_64. GNOME is 2.8.3-2mdk.

Created an attachment (id=23998)
JVM error log

Created an attachment (id=23999)
Eclipse configuration details
Moving to Platform/SWT

Have you tried other GNOME applications that use the new file chooser, do they
crash under GNOME 2.8?  If the crash doesn't happen when you're running under
KDE then I would suspect the gnome-vfs backend to be the trouble, but if that
were true then it shouldn't be unique to eclipse.

None of the other GNOME applications I tried that use the filechooser
experienced any problems.

I also noticed that I didn't have the package gnome-vfs but installing it (and
its depending packages) didn't resolve anything.

You had it already installed.  From your stack trace, the following libraries
were loaded at the time of the crash:

  /usr/lib64/libgnomevfs-2.so.0.800.4
  /usr/lib64/gtk-2.0/2.4.0/filesystems/libgnome-vfs.so
  /usr/lib64/gnome-vfs-2.0/modules/libfile.so

With another GTK+ application, can you try navigating to the Eclipse install
directory and through the Eclipse workspace?  I am not sure exactly what
triggers the use of the libfile.so module but I would like to make sure.

I tried it with GEdit and Totem and both don't crash.

I had Eclipse 3.0.2 lying around and installed that. It runs fine but I noticed
that the filechooser is a different one from those I saw with other GNOME apps.
This is one with a dropdownbox with directories, a listbox with dirs & files and
an inputfield.
The other ones have one the left a listbox with some folders (Home, Desktop,
Filesystem, Floppy, DVD-RW) and on the right a listbox with dirs and files.

Eclipse 3.0.2 uses GtkFileSelection while 3.1 uses GtkFileChooser where
available (it only exists in GTK+ 2.4 or newer).

You're sure the crash only happens when running under GNOME?  Could it be the
LOCALE settings?

I tried IceWM and that's ok too.
I changed the locale from en_US to nl_NL and en_GB. Problem remains.
Can you still reproduce this crash?

First, I got a compilation error:

----------------
[mhurd@sugar swttest]$ javac -classpath swt.jar TestApp.java
TestApp.java:8: gtk_init_check(long[],long[]) in org.eclipse.swt.internal.gtk.OS cannot be applied to (int[],<nulltype>)
        OS.gtk_init_check (new int /*long*/ [] {0}, null);
          ^
1 error
----------------

I changed the line use long instead of int:
        OS.gtk_init_check (new long[] { 0 }, null );

To get it to compile, and got this result on execution:

/home/mhurd/tmp/ccAmNlDQ.o: In function `main':

[mhurd@sugar swtctest]$ pkg-config --cflags --libs gtk+-2.0
-I/usr/include/gtk-2.0 -I/usr/lib64/gtk-2.0/include -I/usr/include/atk-1.0 -I/usr/include/cairo -I/usr/include/pango-1.0 -I/usr/include/glib-2.0 -I/usr/lib64/glib-2.0/include  -L/usr/X11R6/lib64 -lgtk-x11-2.0 -lgdk-x11-2.0 -latk-1.0 -lgdk_pixbuf-2.0 -lpangocairo-1.0 -lpango-1.0 -lcairo -lgobject-2.0 -lgmodule-2.0 -ldl -lglib-2.0 -lfreetype -lfontconfig -lXrender -lX11 -lXext -lpng12 -lz -lm

I got that far by installing the lib64gtk+2.0_0-devel package for my distro (Mandriva 2006 x64).

I'll keep poking at this - but wanted to post the update.

Thanks

Thanks, that's the right fix for the Java code.  The fix to compile the C code is that you also need gthread-2.0 and the development headers for that (I think it should be part of glib), sorry:

  gcc -o chooser chooser.c `pkg-config --cflags --libs gtk+-2.0 gthread-2.0`

Yep - see that now. Result for C prog was:
-----------
success
-----------

[mhurd@sugar swttest]$ gij --version
gij (GNU libgcj) version 3.4.4

Copyright (C) 2002 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
This is free software; see the source for copying conditions.  There is NO
warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.
[mhurd@sugar swttest]$
[mhurd@sugar swttest]$
[mhurd@sugar swttest]$ gij -cp .:./swt.jar TestApp

(<unknown>:5249): GLib-GObject-WARNING **: value "((GtkFileChooserAction) -6105760)" of type `GtkFileChooserAction' is invalid or out of range for property `action' of type `GtkFileChooserAction'
[mhurd@sugar swttest]$

Unfortunately, gij 3.4 is a bit too old, so it is hard to say if this is a bug in gij or a hint about what's causing the crash.

So far, we're still in the situation where the test case code is crashing when run through Java, but the equivalent C code example does not.  Can you try with an IBM VM instead?

With the ibm jvm, the TestApp appears to complete without error:

[mhurd@sugar swttest]$ /opt/ibm-java2-x86_64-50/bin/java -cp .:./swt.jar TestApp
[mhurd@sugar swttest]$
How about Eclipse?  Does it crash with the IBM JVM?
Seems to work! I'll press on things a little harder today, but so far I can't get it to fail anywhere. Thanks.
I wonder if the Sun JVM is maybe not aligning the stack properly when making JNI calls.

Azeem, you helped with bug 71987 which was also 64-bit specific.  Do
you know if there are any known problems with stack alignment for JNI
under the Sun x86-64 JVM, or maybe know who could look at this?  In
this case it's a varargs function that crashes.

Created an attachment (id=33488)
Core file from IBM amd64-1.4.2 VM
Looks like its a crash in libc not in the JVM.  Since the IBM VM also crashes, I'm tempted to say its an Eclipse bug.  Might be bad JNI code, or some issues with SWT/GTK+ interactions?

See comment #12 to comment #23 or so.  Basically, we're calling
a varargs function through a function pointer obtained using dlsym(),
and the x86-64 ABI is very sensitive to the alignment and type of
the arguments.  I'm not sure what's going wrong though, or why
it only happens in some situations and not others.

Chris, can you try all of the test applications from those comments
and see which ones segfault for you?

All results were exactly the same as Mike's using the IBM VM, down to the changing the int array to longs, the warnings, etc.
